text: this is andrew jacobs reporting from
xinjiang china in early october
thousands of young people camped out in
the mud sharing meals cigarettes and
flirting at the four-day midi music
festival in southern jang-soo province
china is experiencing an explosion of
music festivals two years ago there were
just five most of them in beijing this
year there have been nearly a hundred
across the country for chinese youth the
vessels provide a rare opportunity to
break free from social constraints
explore new kinds of music and commune
with like-minded Souls like these
hardcore fans of the death metal band
frosty e festival organizers say the
sudden growth of festivals has much to
do with local governments who once
thought of rock music and its fans as
threatening but who now see festivals as
a way to draw tourist dollars and
youthful hip masti their cities for
indie musicians it's an opportunity to
tour the country connect with fans and
earn some money it's ironic that the
performances are often sponsored by
local governments in the case of the
MIDI festival they provided organizers
two million dollars in grants and
created the festival grounds from
scratch even as the bands perform songs
was sometimes subversive lyrics and acts
of public rebellion like this burning of
a Japanese flag which took place while
the police stood by the burst of
xenophobia was accompanied by the fan
singing the chinese national anthem here
young fans sloshed around the mosh pit
doing a set by the metal band demerit
most festivals are less rambunctious at
the zebra music festival in hangzhou the
crowd included families with children
and the music was even soothing part of
the zebra festivals message was
environmental sustainability and
attendees were encouraged to help
recycle clothing for the needy overall
the music at most vessels tends to be
pop a political hear the hipster popstar
wang xiao kun performs with you
exceptions local governments insists on
approving ban rosters and song list in
advance i am although cynics feared that
the new crop of festivals will simply
become venues from marketing
money-making and consumption others hope
they provide new opportunities for young
musical talent and lead to the
blossoming of a free-spirited youth
culture in china
